posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I love easy puzzles at this stage of my life.

1) To satisfy the Hide (10) prereq for SD requires 17 levels of cross-class.**
2) The maximum number of each prestige class pre-epic is: 10
3) 17 -10 = 7, so the missing level MUST be fighter, either at Level 7 or Level 17...  makes no difference except for a pre-epic Listen or Spot skill dump, if applicable.
4) WM and SD both get bonus at 13, 16, 19, 22, 25, 28 (convenient, huh?)
5) The "chosen" bonus combo... WM 19, SD 13 = 32 levels.  That leaves 8 left for fighter with 7 pre-epic.
6) Therefore, choose either Fighter at Level 21 or Fighter at Level 40.... you can't have both to reach the two bonus feat levels for WM and SD.
7) Stagmeister is correct.  You can take EWF and EWS at Fighter 8 (Level 21) but lose a Grt STR opportunity since WM bonus does not include Grt STR. (i.e. final STR 31).
8) This means you need to start with STR 17 to reach STR 32 so will need to reduce starting CON (and/or perhaps INT or DEX to 13, haven't added this up myself)

** For future reference, the algorithm for the earliest possible level to satisfy a cross-class skill prereq is: (Skill level * 2) - 3, so in this case (10 * 2) - 3 = 20 - 3 = 17.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Why Two Weapon Fighting? If you dual-wield katanas, you will have an extra -2 AB penalty for using a non-small or tiny weapon in your off-hand, and not having Ambidexterity will hurt you AB in the off-hand attack, and the lack of Improved Two Weapon Fighting means that you will be taking all these penalties to gain only one extra attack. You would get a total of -4 AB on your main hand and -8 AB on your off hand. You would be much better off going sword-and-board and taking another feat, like Toughness.

Now, a shield will hurt your stealth, but why do you need stealth anyway? Since you don't have sneak attacks, the only thing you gain by sneaking is avoiding fights, which means avoiding experience points for killing enemies. Besides, ninjas, not samurai, are the stealthy ones.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
KidMiracleman wrote:
Apparently she already has mobility


 
David, we need FULL disclosure to help you fine-tune this toon.  If there are other racial or class bonus(es) in abilities or feats, please list them all when you post your first sample.  I am pleased that you are finally beginning to piece builds together on your own.  It's just a faster way to reach optimization doing it that way, if you are able, than asking for "a good build" for X/Y/Z.

I haven't seen any target on your skill allocation and nothing to infer that you are planning to increase the stealth skills beyond what is needed to qualify for SD.  HiPS can be very powerful in PvM on most servers unless they have imposed an extended cool-down or some such change to how the feat works.  Some just boost the stealth skills temporarily but you must still move beyond perception range to stand a chance to trigger stealth.

The problem with a prospective stealth STR build is that, without the DEX and with equipping armor (any armor at all limits your stealth skills) and shield (check penalty), stealth is really bad.  If you had allocated... let's say 23 ranks to Hide by level 20 and were wearing plate/tower with your katana in hand, your actual skill check would be 23 + 2 DEX - 1 DEX (MDB) - 8 (ACP plate) - 10 (ACP tower) = 6 Hide vs. opposed Spot.   Basically, not even worth investing into stealth beyond the prereq.  With enough feats (there's that need for more fighter levels popping up again), you could at least boost that by 13 via SkF/ESkF up to 19 Hide. That's not heavy-duty stealth, but at least you'd get some use out of HiPS occasionally.

I also understand the kewlness factor of your TWF choice.  Many players like to see the dual-katana animation which is fine.  It still comes down to having fun playing the character so if that adds to your enjoyment, go for it.  But understand that the TWF feat by itself won't really be helping enough to spend a slot on it. You'll still be missing against any challenging creature A LOT and forget about any thought of DWing in PvP.  I suggest just dual-wielding when you want, suffer the combat penalties, and when it seems you can't hit a barn door, switch back to the s/s configuration.  In other words, eliminate TWF for a more useful combat option (like KD) that will work well with s/s.

With all that said, I think you are trying to do too much with all those SD levels staring you in the face.  If getting the clone is important, that's also fine.  But trying to satisfy WM prereqs, establish an effective AB and reach EDR is a bit much.  With more fighter levels, sure, you'd be in a better position, but your choices have pinched you.  WM 19 is usually the same milestone I reach for to avoid the lame Epic Toughness WM gets forced into with more bonus feats.  But with more fighter levels, you could extend both your AB and damage with general feats and still develop your full combat potential (EWF/EWS/Prowess/ArmorSkin).  Just pointing out that your diversification is costing you combat optimization.   We won't consider how abysmal your AC will be since it appears you are depending on a large HP pool and minor EDR to help deal with incoming damage.  Those 15 rounds per day using Shadow Evade will fly by like a blink.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Yeah, with STR builds it is tough not to get hit.  I noticed you tried to use PM to reach high AC in another build, but even that is limited and countered (usually) by your toon's bad AB so you don't get hit as much but you also don't hit back reliably either.

But there are ways to counter destructive, opposed attacks for STR-focus beyond huge HP and EDR. 

We're considering a non-caster in this case, and one of the most common methods is using rogue for UMD to use scrolls of ImpInvis.  Assassin is another and even gets a feat-based version to use besides the UMD benefits.  An opponent's Blind Fight can negate some of the concealment benefits, but 50% concealment really helps, even for only a few turns per scroll.  Both those classes work well with stealth because you can dump to skills regularly without needing to invest too many levels to achieve a good skill set.  Monk's Empty Body concealment is another option but that only provides about 4 turns each day and requires at least monk 18 to gain access to it.  So scrolls are really more economical, class-investment-wise, if available.  Even when effects get dispelled, just read another.  With a big enough stack, you'll expend all the dispeller's slots.... eventually.

The problem with investing so many levels to get the Epic Shadowlord is that at SD 13 it is the bottom-of-the-barrel version with only 132 HP and none of the combat feats that make it a really influential ally.   Perhaps your server has modified the low-end epic summon to have better stats?  Let's hope so, since you are depending so heavily in its effectiveness. By default, its only offensive threat is the touch attack that bypasses AC but its standard attack is lame (i.e. +16/+11/+6).

In comparison, an elder water elemental (for example) is 228 HP, has most of the same immunities of the shadowlord (sneaks, crits, mind, etc.), can be recast as often as the number of scrolls you have in inventory of a UMD-user and attacks at +26/+21/+16 with much more damage.  You can also buff it via ImpInvis scrolls (or any other scrolls, for that matter) to make up for the concealment it lacks compared to the SD summon.  So, there are ways to achieve nearly the same level of support without needing to invest so heavily in SD or really any tumble class.  Without being able to take full advantage of HiPS I think you are fighting yourself from a build's perspective going the SD route.

But you are probably right about needing a huge HP pool in legendary environments.  They usually design encounters that bypass typical toon combat levels so you'll be chugging pots and using heal kits a lot.

BTW, David... you may very well have described aspects of your server in another request but don't rely on us (actually... ME!) remembering all that.  There are too many different servers played by too many requestors to keep track of them.  If you have been playing the same place for a while and plan to continue, perhaps it would be in all our best interests to start a topic in the Persistent Worlds section.  Check some of the PW topics already posted to see the sort of information that an author/player reveals.  Disclose any information you have now and add to it as new facts become available to you.  Don't worry so much about spelling or grammar.  The bare facts are what is most relevant.  Then each time you request a new build intended to be played there, just furnish the link back to it up front. We'll be able to click that first to get a heads-up as to how each new build needs to comply to best serve your needs.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Once you give up the notion of access to the epic shadowlord, there are many more ways open to exploit, as evidenced by the other recommendations. 

One other issue about the chosen samarai "theme"...

Katanas come in a few different lengths that have changed during its evolution.  Not with NWN, but in reality.  NWN only provides a shortened version with a one-hand grip.  And to be historically accurate, the only time it was used to dual-wield was in combination with a dagger-like katana companion with the dagger held in the weaker of the two hands and used for finishing or beheading a beaten adversary.  The only way to get a true samarai-like appearance of the NWN katana is to wield it with a small race.  They don't provide a different Japanese-like stance (i.e.kamae) when using it, though, with the blade's forward extension exaggerated.  Their animation is the same as the longsword animation just with slightly different item blueprint.

So, in order to get a two-handed samarai appearance, the choices are few... errr... one... for a medium race.  A greatsword is about as close as you'd get to a 2-handed katana. 

I never heard mention, viewed any footage or witnessed any competition while in Asia of a samarai using a katana with a shield, either.  In dueling, they use the hilt to block attacks.  Katana was never used on the battlefield due to its short range compared to opponents spears, halberd, etc. negating any threat of being attacked. It is strictly designed for one-on-one combat.  Uma's escapades with her Hanzo special seem to debunk this claim, but then again, when doesn't Hollywood produce fairy tales to titillate the ruminating box office throng?

To be fair, NwN is a fantasy RPG, so perhaps a few inexactitudes in the actualite can be forgiven - after all, the greatsword was actually mostly used as a bludgeoning weapon to unhorse cavalry, and the shield was used as much as an offensive weapon as a defensive tool, with a slashing short sword used once the opponent had been battered by the shield. Equally, longswords were seldom used with a shield, the wielder using their vambraces to deflect thrusts. But we could go on all day about these things...

Oh, in Aielund, a nodachi (as well as other less westernised weaponry) is available in the exotic stores, certainly up to +3 enhancement. This has been represented as a more slender, "katana-esque" two-handed blade (and it comes under the greatsword banner, rather than katana, so it may be used without taking Exotic Weapon Proficiency), although, as Hip says, the wielder's stance does remain the same as for the greatsword.

My reference to the greatsword was clearly described as a best-fit solution using NWN default resources for a medium race and nothing more than that.  I'd be forced to use either a halfling or gnome to more closely mimic a realistic use of the katana as a samurai warrior within the limitations.  But who knows?  Perhaps David's server does provide a 2H version for medium races.

I am a disciple of the PnP world where realistic elements are integral to the game and enhance the enjoyment IMMENSELY.  That's why you still have dungeoneers 25 years still rolling dice.  Actually, almost nobody plays AD&D face-to-face unless it is roleplayed.   But electronic RP has become extremely popular within the most recent NWN servers and, as you have alluded to, at times gear customizations have been provided to improve on the default limitations of the game.  A thematic build is a roleplay build.  Whether it is attended to fully or not by the player is the player's choice, but that doesn't change its intent.

You'll need to research your Japanese military history better.  Shields were a temporary European staple, essentially a hellenistic by-product which found its way into Rome and then further North, a form of defense which was discarded when plate armor became predominant.  But I was referring to soldiering in the orient, not within Western influence.

Bottom line:  NWN provides the tools to deliver as realistic an experience as the designer (and the prospective target audience) are seeking.  "Fantasy" only means nobody really dies, not that laser guns might appear from a time warp.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Sorry Hip, I wasn't attempting to have a pop in the slightest. For once, I was actually trying to be forgiving of the game's foibles! I certainly don't pretend to knowledge of oriental warfare, and wasn't attempting to profess any. Indeed, my knowledge of most western warfare is limited: I was merely being illustrative of how problematic it can be for electronic designers to cover the full gamut of options. Nor was I attempting to undercut what you said about the greatsword (though we can argue about shields elsewhere
